results.title: Projecting motion pictures
results.creator_credit: William Jordan and University of California. Dept. of Theatre Arts. Motion Picture Division
results.brief_description: The most important thing a projectionist does is present a film, not just run a projector. The film presumes the student projectionist has a knowledge of the equipment which they are to operate. Stress is on the relationship between the audience and the elements of projecting - seating, screen, loudspeaker, projector and the projection procedure - rather than on the purely mechanical aspects of projection.

results.title: Project Tinkertoy
results.creator_credit: United States. Dept. of the Navy
results.brief_description: A report on a joint US Navy-National Bureau of Standards project to develop a new system of electronics design and manufacture. this uses the ‘building block’ principle by which resistors, capacitors, tube rockets and other parts of common design are assembled by machines into functional electronic parts.
results.description: A report on a joint US Navy-National Bureau of Standards project to develop a new system of electronics design and manufacture. this uses the ‘building block’ principle by which resistors, capacitors, tube rockets and other parts of common design are assembled by machines into functional electronic parts.

results.title: Project for plenty
results.creator_credit: V.R. Sarma, M Bilavaana and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: A report on the building of the Hirakud Dam, one of the schemes undertaken by the government of India to develop the country’s potential resources. The film illustrates building activity at the actual dam site and the dykes and canals which are being constructed to harness the waters of the Mahanadi River and bring new highways, bridges, rail-line, electricity, thriving townships and prosperity to a valley and its people.

results.title: Project for all seasons
results.creator_credit: Jim White and Canadian International Development Agency
results.brief_description: describes a project funded by Canada and the World Bank to aid agriculture, grazing and road building in Africa. The project also built an administration centre and a town of 85 houses. They helped to provide employment so that their menfolk working down mines in South Africa could return home.

results.title: Project 500 Kv
results.brief_description: Tells the story of the stringing of high voltage cables across the Gippsland countryside. Working with electric line transmissions oat half a million volts is difficult work and both the testing of the apparatus and the building of the towers and lines provide many spectacular scenes.

results.title: Project 074
results.creator_credit: Peter De Normanville and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: The standard method of measuring engine wear is to weigh a piston ring before and after a long period of running. A far less laborious procedure makes use of a radio-active piston ring; radiating particles worn from the ring circulate in the lubricating oil, and their abundance, which can be accurately measured, gives a practically instantaneous indication of engine wear. All this is explained in this film, and views of the Harwell atomic pile are also shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter De Normanville and Shell Film Unit

results.title: Progress: the story of the Rootes Group
results.creator_credit: Cecil Musk and Edward W. Beckett
results.brief_description: Traces the history of the Rootes Group of factories, manufacturers of automobiles and aircraft. Shows the Rootes workshop 40 years ago; the use of mechanized equipment in WW1; amalgamation with the Humber organization; rationalization of the Rootes group resulting in decreased production costs and increased quality of products. The major part of the film illustrates the magnitude of the part played by the Rootes group in manufacturing armoured cars, trucks, bombers, and fighters during WW2.

results.title: Progress with precision
results.brief_description: Visits various industrial centres in England and shows how Capstan and Turret Lathes are made. All the elaborate components are examined, along with the finished machines.
